description.overview: Fixers are tech-savvy rogues and experts in digital warfare who excel in infiltration, extraction, and control of the battlefield. With their unique Grid Armor and advanced understanding of nanotechnology, they serve as the linchpins of any strategic operation.

system.flashback_trigger: When earlier hacking or technical setup could have solved a current obstacle.
system.flashback_effect: Roll to disclose that you had already hacked a system or set up equipment to aid in your current goal.
system.signature_resource_desc:
The Fixer's body is enveloped in shimmering digital code, a visible sign of their consciousness partially phasing into gridspace. This armor not only hardens their physical form against attacks but also blends elements of the digital world into their reality, enhancing their defensive capabilities. With each moment spent in Grid Armor, the fixer’s physical form starts to flicker with static, their voice carries a distorted echo.
But as the fixer overextends their stay in Grid Armor, they begin to lose touch with reality. Their form becomes translucent, their movements erratic, as if they are in a state of buffering. This is a process called Fading. When the digital world takes over them, they can struggle to differentiate between the physical and virtual world, causing disorientation and confusion.
system.signature_resource_effect:
Starts at d6 Power Die starting at 1. This die represents the Fixer's current level of integration with the Grid Armor's capabilities.
As a reaction, the Fixer can tap into Grid armor for the round, gaining the following benefits.
  • Initiative Bonus: You gain an initiative bonus in combat equal to the current level of the Power Die.
  • Physical Evasion Bonus: you gain a bonus to physical evasion tests equal to the Power Die level.
  • Recharge: Each time you successfully avoid an attack, heal NP equal to 2 x the Power Die level.
  • Phasing: Gain the ability to move through creatures or objects, treating it as difficult terrain, you cannot finish your movement in the phased location. Failing to reach the other end will shunt you back to your original location.

Usage: Each time the Fixer taps into the Grid Armor for its benefits, tick the power die by one.
Risk: Fading (Overloading the Grid Armor):
If the Power Die reaches 6, it indicates the Grid Armor has been pushed to its limits, leading to a state called "Fading."
During Fading, the Fixer spends a round buffering – a period of vulnerability where they appear in a random location and cannot move until the start of the next Round.
Post-buffering, the Power Die resets to 1, and the Fixer can start using the Grid Armor's capabilities again.

signature_traits.name: Fixer Grid
signature_traits.description:
Fixers have access to a “Decommissioned” beta version of the Grid, Version F.1337 and can navigate this specialized digital network exclusive to their profession.
Access: The Fixer can tap into the F Grid, a digital dimension parallel to the physical world, using their unique NCU genetic coding.
Navigation: Within the F Grid, the Fixer can traverse vast distances in the physical world almost instantaneously, effectively teleporting from one location to another.
Utility: The Grid can be used for rapid travel, escaping danger, or reaching otherwise inaccessible areas. It may also serve as a means to gather information or deploy digital assets.
Limitations: Whenever you exit the F Grid, it puts heavy strain on your body, leaving you with 1 HP. Accessing the F Grid more than once a mission is a risk, and can draw attention to malicious code that still exists in the system

signature_traits.name: Corporate Infiltrator (Downtime)
signature_traits.description:
A secret among fixers is the backdoor to Omni-Pol’s supply channels that exists within the grid. During downtime you can bypass sophisticated protocols to access restricted information or resources.
You can choose 1 of the following each time during downtime.

  • Advanced Cybersecurity Protocols: Details on the latest digital defense mechanisms, which could be used to enhance the Fixer's own security or to breach other secure systems.
  • Blueprints and Tech Schematics: Designs for cutting-edge technology, which could be sold, used to create new gadgets, or offered to allies as a bargaining chip.
  • Operational Intelligence: Information on Omni-Pol operations, including troop movements, future plans, or high-value targets, useful for strategic planning in upcoming missions.

Dummy Order Attachment: To avoid detection, the Fixer must cleverly attach their dummy order to an existing legitimate order. This means the Fixer can specify the category (like information or grid warp weapons and ammo) but cannot control the exact model or type of the weapon or exact piece of information. The outcome depends on the nature of the linked legitimate order, adding an element of unpredictability to the hack. This method greatly reduces the risk of getting caught but introduces a level of uncertainty regarding the specific item to be received.
